title.narrative: Prodoc Sustainable Financing of the Protected Area System in Mozambique MITUR
SUSTAINABLE FINANCING OF THE PROTECTED AREA SYSTEM IN MOZAMBIQUE MID-TERM REVIEW

description.narrative: The project objective is to strengthen the overall effectiveness and sustainability of Mozambique's protected area system, including financial sustainability, through working partnerships between private, NGO and community stakeholders.

participating-org.narrative: FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE
UN Department of Safety and Security
UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)

Environment - policy, planning and administration

Financial plan for system of protected areas adopted by government

comment.narrative:
Financial plan for system of protected areas adopted by government: No
Achievement (%) of performance targets detailed in the PA agency's Annual Performance Plan: No Plan
Number of protected areas with business plans that enable the sourcing of adequate funds for the implementation of PA management plan: 3
Ratio of human resource to operational costs in PA agency: PA agency still to be established
Number of protected area staff completing in-house specialized financial management training and skills development programmes: 0
Recruitment of staff to approved posts in the organogram of new PA agency (% of posts with staff appointed): 0
% of audit queries adequately resolved by PA agency: N/A

- Financial Plan for Protected Areas system finalized - Law Enforcement Strategy for PAs developed - Management Plans for 3 PAs (Reserves of Pomene and Marromeu, and Magoe National Park) developed - Bazaruto Natural Park management plan revised and updated

(i) A financial plan for PA’s system finalized. Main guidance indicates that there is need for the Management of the entire PA system reflects on the fees for entrance to the PA, which is one of the main income sources that needs to be reviewed based on the potential of each PA. (ii) Key strategic areas for the conservation law identified. Pending to development of respective regulations. (iii) Initiated the development of the 3 management plans for Pomene and Marromeu Reserves, as well as for Magoe National Park. (iv) First draft of Bazaruto Natural Park management plan being reviewed for submission to approval by the National Authority.

description.narrative: Objective Strengthen the overall effectiveness and sustainability of Mozambiques Protected Area System including financial sustainability through working partnerships between public private NGO and community stakeholders
1 Financial sustainability scorecard for national system of protected areas

comment.narrative: greater than 45

Approaching the target 38 The Financial Scorecard was applied There is a general change to the baseline and a limited change compared to the past year but some of the objective of the project will be achieved In particular Legal regulatory and institutional frameworks are in a good level The level of Business planning and tools for costeffective management is poor The level will increase as the ANAC Financial Plan is concluded the ANAC Business Plan is in progress and two other consultancies on revenue generationcanalization mechanisms will be finalized until this year In addition ANAC is currently developing the regulations for the recently approved Conservation Law All this tools will improve the legal and the institutional frameworks as well as the operational activities in the ANAC and PAs system The score of Tools for revenue generation by PA system will also increase for the same reasons

description.narrative: 2 Capacity development indicator score for protected area system

comment.narrative:
Systemic 46
Institutional 46 Individual 35

Systemic 60
Institutional 55
Individual 50

Approaching the target Systemic 49 Institutional 49 Individual 76 There are not significant changes comparing to the baseline and only marginal progress has been made For systemic and Institutional level the activities in progress will improve the scores as there are some changes in the ANACs management structure For the individual one the critical situation in Gorongosa is in part overpassed and actually some activities useful to improve the indicators levels has been developed The results can be considered very good This fact can be considered also a success story in the biodiversity conservation policies in Mozambique With new Government after 2014 elections the management of PAs system was moved from the Ministry of Tourism MITUR to newly created Ministry of Land Environment and Rural Development MITADER This has created an added value to the PAs system as some of regulatory instruments were dependent to former Ministry for Coordination of Environmental Affairs MICOA which mandates now belongs to the same ministry MITADER

description.narrative: 13 Total area as a of the original extent of evergreen forest on Gorongosa Mountain above 700m deforested

comment.narrative: more than 36

Cannot inform the indicator Due to continued security issues it has not been possible for the GRP staff to access the Mountain with the exception of small section close to Niankoukou and the Murombodzi waterfall There have also been no overflights with a helicopter during this period Consequently it has not been possible to assess the situation with regards to forest clearing It is planned to commission a new highresolution submeter pixel satellite image around AprilJune 2016 for comparison with the 2013 image

description.narrative: 17 Number of wildlfires larger than1 km2 in the Gorongosa Mountain above 700m

comment.narrative: Baseline and target reconstruction would be needed because adequate data on this was not available at project start Baseline and targets were established not very stringently New data is available now Yet from all indications progress is good with room for improvement A historical analysis of the NASA FIRMS data has now been completed for the main historical Park for the period 20002013 The average fire return interval is 32 years which translates to 31 of the Park being burned every year This is in line with Fire Return Intervals recorded for other large tropical savanna ecosystems such as Niassa This analysis has brought up some methodological issues which will need to be considered in the analysis of the data for the Mountain In any case is reasonable considering that the indicator level is good but can be improved

description.narrative: 18 Average monthly household income of the Canda Sandjungira and Tambara communities US

comment.narrative: Indicator cannot be assessed No updates to the indicator Household surveys were not carried out however it is important to note that 20 hectares of coffee have been established on Mt Gorongosa that will lead to future income In the interim there is inter row cropping that is providing improved household income The project includes the planting of indigenous trees to support reforestation targets The coffee project is not adequately represented in the current indicators

title.narrative: Adaptation in the Coastal Zones of Mozambique

description.narrative: The project has 2 Outcomes relating to the development of adaptive capacity to manage the effects of climate change on coastal resources. The project has 4 indicators and targets that measure adaptive capacity, in line with the GEF V Results Framework.

title.narrative: Adaptation in the Coastal Zones of Mozambique
Adaptation in the Coastal Zones of Mozambique
Adaptation in the Coastal Zones of Mozambique
Adaptation in the Coastal Zones of Mozambique
Adaptation in the Coastal Zones of Mozambique

description.narrative: The project will tackle barriers in relation to weak inter-sectoral policy coordination and development, low institutional and individual capacity to plan for climate change, and financial constraints.
capital of a political entity
second-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Creation of community resilience and livelihood

description.narrative: second-order administrative division
second-order administrative division

% of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender)
1. Capacity Perception Index
2. Number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimize exposure to climate variability
Adaptive capacity of coastal communities improved and coastal zone resilience to climate change enhanced.
1. % of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender)
2. % change in income generation in targeted area given existing and projected climate change.
3. % of population with access to improved flood and drought management, disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative:
National data and information relevant to coastal erosion and climate change risk management is currently very limited. Some climatic records focusing on a few weather parameters are held in government departments, but detailed records of more complex variables such as stream flow and sediment transport which can help development of a more robust CC risk profile of coastal zones are few in number.
Lack of data and poor management of physical coastal data presents a barrier to adequate monitoring and forecasting of the impacts of climate change on coastal zones. Responsibility for development and implementation of coastal land use planning legislation and relevant regulatory frameworks is also fragmented and duplicated across different sectors and government departments. Existing laws often are not applied or enforced. Decision-makers at national, sub-national and at local level are not informed and trained to extract/use environmental data and information, particularly that related to SLR and coastal erosion, to adjust municipal land use regulations and investment planning for CC coastal risk management. Access to mass media and other IT communication systems in rural areas is low, and illiteracy rates are high which pose a challenge to the dissemination of climate risk information. Average illiteracy level in Mozambique is about 56.7%, but much higher among women (71.2%). Furthermore, the most illiterate people live in the rural areas (INE, 2009). OUTCOME 1
OUTCOME 2: Baseline: Historical records from 1960-2005 point to a warming trend, particularly in central and north Mozambique of 1.1-1.6 ºC in maximum temperatures which can be significantly higher for the lowland coastal areas. In addition the analysis of these past records also indicates significant increases in duration of heat waves, as well as a delay in the start of the rainfall season. Furthermore to this, maximum temperatures are expected to increase by 2.5-3.0 ºC in the interior by 2040-2060.
Coas

Output 1.1. A dynamic monitoring system for dunes, beaches, mangroves and sea level rise established to measure topographic, oceanographic, chemical and biological indicators (INGC).
Output 1.3 Coastal erosion risk profiles prepared for multiple coastal segment of 2 km of extension (INGC)
Output 1.4 Land-use planning guidelines developed that incorporate the coastal erosion risk profiles. (MICOA)
Output 1.5 Toolkit developed outlining methodologies used to assess climate change risks, adaptation planning and implementation, cost effectiveness analysis and a replication plan for Mozambique. (INGC).
Output 1.6. Agricultural extension Services trained to support vulnerable communities in Pemba, Pebane and Závora to transition to climate-resilient livelihoods (MINAG; INAM; IIAM).
Output 1.7. Partnership established between INAM- Agromet Advisory Service (AAS), CES and the Media Institute (ICS) to broadcast through community radio climate forecasts and adaptation advice (MINAG; IIAM, INGC).
Output 2.1 Micro-financing extended to each of the seven project sites in Pemba, Pebane and Inharrime, to disburse adaptation financing and capacity development for livelihood enhancement and diversification, to reduce vulnerability to climate change. (MICOA).
Output 2.2 Adaptation investment plan developed for each of the seven pilot sites in Pemba, Pebane and Inharrime for community-level CCA measures such as small-scale infrastructure and ecosystem-based measures. (MICOA).
Output 2.3 Priority community-based adaptation projects implemented among 10,000 households in the seven pilot sites in Pemba, Pebane and Inharrime, focused on resilient livelihoods and community-level adaptation measures, including ecosystem protection and enhancement (MICOA).
Output 2.4 Learning and results disseminated to promote replication through public awareness campaigns, exposure visits and national workshop (MICOA).

Under outcome 1 (climate change risks to coastal zones integrated into key decision-making process and managed at community level as well as sub-national and national government level), the planed results are: created a data base using the information provided constantly by the community volunteers; Installed 3 meteorological stations; updated the community mappings based on data from community groups and field surveys; produced local maps on climate vulnerabilities and risks and Training’s developed and conducted to reduce the Impacts of climate change on agriculture and fishery For the outcome 2 (Adaptive capacity of coastal communities improved and coastal zone resilience to climate change enhanced) which is divided in two sub windows through Microfinance Institutions and Community investments plans. For the first sub window, the expected results are: allocated 50% of the credit line that will lead the Microfinance Institutions to have 25% of active clients, 30% of clients are women, 40% of clients has diversified and increased source of incomes on one hand, on another hand it is expected that the MFI delivery innovative products and services that includes technical assistance that will help the communities doing activities on agriculture, fishery and small business that are resilient to climate change. On the second window it is expected to have 60 % of the Investments measures implemented.

description.narrative: To develop capacity of communities living in the coastal zone to manage climate change risks
of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative: Coastal communities lack the resources or support to strengthen their resilience against CC induced hazards
At the end of the project 50 of men and women have declared ownership of adaptation processes disaggregated by gender
Substantial progress has been made in regards to the Development Objectives At the moment 14 of men and 9 of women declare ownership of the adaptation processes

description.narrative: Adaptive capacity of coastal communities improved and coastal zone resilience to climate change enhanced

1 of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes disaggregated by gender
2 change in income generation in targeted area given existing and projected climate change
3 of population with access to improved flood and drought management disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative:
The VCA consultations during the PPG phase have shown that though aware of their vulnerability and that of the surrounding ecosystem farmers fishermen and all those whose livelihoods are affected by CC induced hazards at the district and community level have no financial resources and knowledge for resilience decision making in the face of droughts and floods
The coastal management expert report revealed that there is currently no protection measures being undertaken by communities against sea level rise and storm surges

At the end of the project 50 of men and women in the selected project sites have declared ownership of adaptation processes disaggregated by gender
By the end of the project 50 of households in the pilot sites have increased their income by 50
50 of households have improved flood and drought management

Adaptation measures have been validated and prioritized at the community level and technical partners increasing ownership of adaptation process Community investment plans have been prepared submitted and approved by the Investment committee Access to finance and training Inhambane 5 demonstration fields in place SDAE working with same number of 1215 members group with 98 women 1 womens group 5 People trained and equipped for chicken production and received inkind loan chicks and food from FDM hired microfinance service provider for this project site 1 womens group organized and trained for swine production and building pigpen FDM This represents innovative production technology into low productivity agricultural and breeding practices For the other two project sites Cabo Delgado and Zambezia no activity reported for community training Microfinance institutions have been hired and started to work in all communities In Inharime Inhambane province FDM was contracted Diagnostic study realized Staff trained in saving and credit group methodology and 1 staff hired to work full time in Sihane community 6 savings and credit groups trained and active saved 64115 Mts 2 groups being prepared for inkind loans for chicken amp swine production All participants SCG Production groups receiving business training and financial education In Pemba Cabo Delgado province CCOM was contracted To date 20 credit officers were trained to work in the 3 communities and in their production areas out of town 3 service centers have been established A specialized institution hired by MFI to train its staff in the savings and credit group methodology Training ongoing with first groups to be formed by the end of July 2015 14 solidarity groups received loan 70 people for MZN 45500000 33 individuals loans provided 6 Women 18 for MZN 136 Million Total value of loans MZN 1815 Million of which 26500000 already paid back 5 ind 1 group All loans for small business petty trade that will contribute to households income All beneficiaries received training in business skills

description.narrative: Climate change risks to coastal zones integrated into key decisionmaking process and managed at community level as well as subnational and national government level
1 Capacity Perception Index

comment.narrative:
Capacity Assessment score 2455
The project will improve the capacity of local Govt to i to engage in stakeholder dialogue to understand needs and priorites for CCA ii the capacity to develop a climate risk problem analysis and create a vision and mandate for CCA initiatives iii to formulate policy and strategy on CCA initiatives 4 the capacity to budget manage and implement CCA initiatives
The scorecard uses 10 indicators deemed by stakeholders to be the most important capacity gaps
Capacity Assessment score 3835

Continued support has been provided to key government institutions at the subnational level in integration of CCA initiatives in their planning cycle These included key partnerships with the National Disaster Management Institute Municipality of Pemba District Authorities of Pebane and Inharrime National Meteorological Institute Agricultural Research Institute the Center for Sustainable Development Higher School of Marine Sciences Eduardo Mondlane University Marine Administration and the recently established Climate Change Knowledge Center at the Academy of Science of Mozambique Initial training in GIS and GPS usage and data collection have been undertaken in the three project sites Pemba Pebane and Zavora for development of CC risk mapsprofiles to further inform the planning system Climate information systems have been improved since project inception to support incorporation of CC risks into decisionmaking and planning

description.narrative: 1 Sustainability of the Protected Area System institutionalized
10 Recruitment of staff to approved posts in the organogram of new PA agency of posts with staff appointed

comment.narrative:
Making progress towards the target
55
The ANAC PA agency should recruit 73 staff members
Actually staff members deployed redeployed from other public administration offices fixed aides and fixed consultants are 40
Some directors and chiefs of department were recruited last years
Its important to underline that this GEF project does not contribute directly to staff recruitment

description.narrative: 11 of audit queries adequately resolved by PA agency

comment.narrative: NA
More than 80

Still Not possible to report progress at this stage The financial plan is under implementation When audits are regularly carried out on ANACs finance the project will be able to report on it We report though on the audit exercises on PROFIN this project for which the target would be achieved Four UNDP audit queries were addressed and resolved

description.narrative: 5 Financial plan for system of protected areas adopted by government

comment.narrative: No
Yes
Approaching the target The Financial Plan was concluded and its expected that in the coming months the Government will adopt it

description.narrative: 6 Achievement of performance targets detailed in the PA agencys Annual Performance Plan

comment.narrative: No plan

The indicator cannot be assessed at this stage The ANAC Annual Performance Plan was produced and is beginning to be implemented A baseline for the performance of the PA agency was established Now there are metrics for measuring performance but at least one full year needs to be concluded for the project to be able to assess progress in this indicator What is to be highlighted is the projects role in facilitating the preparation of the plan

description.narrative: 7 Number of protected areas with business plans that enable the sourcing of adequate funds for the implementation of PA management plan

comment.narrative: Approaching the target The PAs System Financial Plan collected the available information about the PAs Business Plans 6 PAs have a Business Plan Bazaruto Limpopo Quirimbas Zinave Lago Niassa Ilhas Primeiras e Secundas draft Under this GEF projects umbrella 3 Management Plans Pomene Marromeu Magoe will be produced They will include the related business plans Then Bazarutos Management Plan and Business Plan are under revision

comment.narrative: PA agency still to be established

60 40
human resource operating costs

Costs for human resources USD 323000
Operational costs USD 367000
Ratio 46 53
For the current year the provision ANAC Strategic Plan is the following
Costs for human resources USD 05 million
Operational costs USD 13 million
Ratio 30 70

Jan to June 2015 79944
July to Dec 2014 59000
Total during the last 12 months 138944

description.narrative: 13 Total area as a of the original extent of evergreen forest on Gorongosa Mountain above 700m deforested

comment.narrative: more than 36

Cannot inform the indicator Due to continued security issues it has not been possible for the GRP staff to access the Mountain with the exception of small section close to Niankoukou and the Murombodzi waterfall There have also been no overflights with a helicopter during this period Consequently it has not been possible to assess the situation with regards to forest clearing It is planned to commission a new highresolution submeter pixel satellite image around AprilJune 2016 for comparison with the 2013 image

description.narrative: 14 Number of agriculture clearings more than 1ha in extent in the Gorongosa Mountain above 700m

comment.narrative: less than 100

Cannot inform the indicator Due to continued security issues it has not been possible for the GRP staff to access the Mountain with the exception of small section close to Niankoukou and the Murombodzi waterfall Consequently it has not been possible to assess the situation with regards to any new clearings for agricultural purposes It is planned to commission a new highresolution submeter pixel satellite image around AprilJune 2016 for comparison with the 2013

description.narrative: 15 Cost of enforcement and compliance in the proposed GNP expansion area USDkm2year

comment.narrative: less than 100

Data Provided by the Park Administration indicates for 208
Target achieved

description.narrative: 16 Number of communitybased rangers employed by GNP

comment.narrative:
Approaching the target
Total number of communitybased rangers employed by GNP 24

description.narrative: 17 Number of wildlfires larger than1 km2 in the Gorongosa Mountain above 700m

comment.narrative: Baseline and target reconstruction would be needed because adequate data on this was not available at project start Baseline and targets were established not very stringently New data is available now Yet from all indications progress is good with room for improvement A historical analysis of the NASA FIRMS data has now been completed for the main historical Park for the period 20002013 The average fire return interval is 32 years which translates to 31 of the Park being burned every year This is in line with Fire Return Intervals recorded for other large tropical savanna ecosystems such as Niassa This analysis has brought up some methodological issues which will need to be considered in the analysis of the data for the Mountain In any case is reasonable considering that the indicator level is good but can be improved

description.narrative: 18 Average monthly household income of the Canda Sandjungira and Tambara communities US

comment.narrative: Indicator cannot be assessed No updates to the indicator Household surveys were not carried out however it is important to note that 20 hectares of coffee have been established on Mt Gorongosa that will lead to future income In the interim there is inter row cropping that is providing improved household income The project includes the planting of indigenous trees to support reforestation targets The coffee project is not adequately represented in the current indicators

description.narrative: 19 Number of employed community members in reforestation activities and tourism ventures

comment.narrative: Approaching the target 79 of which 51 are forestry workers 24 are rangers and 4 are technicians

Nr. of Mine Free Districts; Nr. of square meters of mine suspected area; Nr. of annual mine and UXO casualties; Nr. of Provinces trained to handle residual explosive remnants of war issues; Quantity of reports and maps with sex and age disaggregated data produced and distributed.

comment.narrative: 86 Districts declared Mine Free (DEC 2011); 10.5 million sq. meters of mine suspected area (JAN2011); 15 mine/UXO related causalities recorded in 2011; Four Provinces trained to handle residual explosives remnants of war issues; 10 maps and reports produced without sex and age disaggregated data in 2011.

1st Quarter 2nd Quarter Results: 1) Number of Mine Free Districts as of 30 June 2015: 128 mine-free districts. 2) No mine suspected area remaining by June 2015; 3) Number of provinces trained in residual ERW issues: 2 provinces 3) 26 maps and reports produced with sex and age disaggregated data in 2014.
3rd Quarter Results: 1) Government Declaration of Mozambique free of all known areas 2) Number of provinces trained in residual ERW issues: 1 province
4th Quarter - 2014 Final results: 1) The APMBT confirmed Mozambique accomplished with Article 5 2) Number of provinces trained in residual ERW issues:1 provinces

description.narrative: Strengthening access to justice, rule of law and human rights protection in Mozambique

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of men with access to legal aid services
Number of women with access to legal aid services
Total number of people with access to legal aid services

The project will support the introduction/strengthening of innovative justice instruments (alternatives to imprisonment, Palaces of Justice), increased awareness of HRs by vulnerable groups and establishment of the National Human Rights Commission

participating-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

description.narrative: independent political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT
UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT
UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

description.narrative: a) Number of necessary legal instruments on alternatives to imprisonment adopted; Number of prosecutors, judges and defense attorneys capacitated on alternatives to imprisonment by 2015; b) Number of UPR recommendations implemented and acted upon; number of training events on good functioning of the Palaces of Justice and their capacity to interact with community courts; c) Percentage of claims processed by the NHRC; Number of study sessions attended by comissioners and NHRC staff

comment.narrative: a) Draft law on alternatives to imprisonment approved by Council of Ministers and submitted to Parliament for approval. b)3 Palaces of Justice established in Morrumbene, Cheringoma and Moma; National Plan for the Protection of Human Rights approved. c) Law on National Human Rights Comission approved by Parliament; the selection process for members of the commission currently being carried out

- Members of the new Department for Execution of Sentences trained on local legal framework and International standards - A nation-wide review conference on the functioning of the Palaces of Justice and the communication between HoJ and informal Justice providers is supported - The drafting of the new National Report for the next cycle of UPR supported - Support the capacity of the Commissioners and Secretariat Staff to regularly visit Provinces

- 4 provincial seminars have been organized by the Supreme Court and the Correctional Services (SERNAP) to build capacities on alternatives to imprisonment - 4 provincial seminars have been organized to build capacities and improve understanding on the new Penal Code within each of the institutions - Drafting of the National Report for the next cycle of UPR completed. Report submitted to the Human Rights Council - Commissioners of the National Human Rights Commission visited prisons and hospitals in the provinces of Maputo, Gaza, Manica and Sofala, making recommendations for improvement of the conditions of inmates. The visits helped in the release of at least 30 convicted, by accelerating their requests for parole.

- 88 staff members of the correctional services at central and provincial levels with trained on alternatives to imprisonment; - 50 Magistrates (judges and prosecutors) benefiting from workshops on alternatives to imprisonment. - 20% of UPR recommendations implemented - At least awareness raising events held and 2 TV spots broadcasted on human rights matters

- 587 staff of the correctional services trained on alternatives to imprisonment; - Over 50 Magistrates participated in workshops on alternatives to imprisonment - The target was not assessed, since there is a new UPR recommendation and the respective Action Plan has not being formulated - 4 TV spots and over 18000 leaflets on awareness raising campaigns on human rights and the rights of vulnerable groups

AWP 2015 expected result 1 - The country programme monitored and evaluated according to its efficiency, effectiveness, relevance and sustainability. Indicators and targets: 1. % of field visits report recommendations implemented. Target: 95%
2015 Expected result 2. The coordination capacity of MINEC enhanced in implementation of the country programme Indicators and targets: 1. Number of country programme board meetings organized. Target: 2 2. Number of MINEC staff trained on project management. Target: 3 3. Number of IP institutions staff attending training in RBM/PME/NIM. Target: 15
2015 AWP Expected result 3. Annual NIM/NGO audit exercise compelted on time. Indicators and targets: 1. Timeliness of annual audit. Target: All submitted by end of April. 2. % of audit recommendations implemented. Target: 90%
2015 AWP expected result 4 Technical capacity of implementing partners and UNDP country office staff strengthened in RBM/PME. Indicators and targets: 1. Level of participation in RBM/PME training. Target: 80%. 2. Number of IP institutions staff attending RBM/PME/NIM trainings. Target: 15 3. Number of RBM/PME/NIM trainings conducted in 2015. Target: 3
2015 AWP expected result 5 Institutional capacities of MINEC and UNDP maintained in support of the effective delivery of the country programme. Indicators and targets: 1. % of country programme delivery rate. Target: 90% 2. Quality of M&E database. Target: M&E Analysis done.

AWP 2015 expected result 1. Indicator and target: % of field visits report recommendations implemented. Target: 95%
2015 report: 73% of field visits implemented - Comment: The 2015 field visit report was elaborated jointly (MINEC-UNDP) and contained recommendations at both strategic and project level. A total of 19 recommendations were implemented out of the 26 provided.
2015 Expected result 2. Indicators and targets: Number of country programme board meetings organized. Target: 2
2015 report: 1 Programme Board held in 2015 at MINEC.
2015 AWP Expected result 3. Indicators and targets: 1. Timeliness of annual audit. Target: All submitted by end of April. 2. % of audit recommendations implemented. Target: 90%
2015 report: 1. 2014 FY audit reports were not submitted by the deadline. 2. Target not met. Based on the OAI review conducted on the 2014 FY audit exercise, 89% of the recommendations were implemented or under implementation.
2015 AWP expected result 4. Indicators and targets: 1. Level of participation in RBM/PME training. Target: 80%.
2015 report: In 2015, due to Government re-structuring which affected the IPs staff of most of the projects, no RBM/PME training was conducted.
2015 AWP expected result 5. Indicators and targets: 1. % of country programme delivery rate. Target: 90% 2. Quality of M&E database. Target: M&E Analysis done.
2015 report: 1. To be confirmed at the end of 2015 fiscal year (Mid January 2016) 2. Target met. The M&E analysis was conducted as part of the annual reporting process, including at Country Programme level.

AWP 2016 expected result 1 - The country programme monitored and evaluated according to its efficiency, effectiveness, relevance and sustainability. Indicators and targets: 1. % of field visits report recommendations implemented. Target: 95%
2016 Expected result 2. The coordination capacity of MINEC enhanced in implementation of the country programme Indicators and targets: 1. Number of country programme board meetings organized. Target: 2 2. Number of MINEC staff trained on project management. Target: 3 3. Number of IP institutions staff attending training in RBM/PME/NIM. Target: 15
2016 AWP Expected result 3. Annual NIM/NGO audit exercise compelted on time. Indicators and targets: 1. Timeliness of annual audit. Target: All submitted by end of April. 2. % of audit recommendations implemented. Target: 90%
2016 AWP expected result 4 Technical capacity of implementing partners and UNDP country office staff strengthened in RBM/PME. Indicators and targets: 1. Level of participation in RBM/PME training. Target: 75%. 2. Number of IP institutions staff attending RBM/PME/NIM trainings. Target: 12 3. Number of RBM/PME/NIM trainings conducted in 2015. Target: 3
2016 AWP expected result 5 Institutional capacities of MINEC and UNDP maintained in support of the effective delivery of the country programme. Indicators and targets: 1. % of country programme delivery rate. Target: 90% 2. Quality of M&E database. Target: M&E Analysis done.

AWP 2016 expected result 1. Indicator and target: % of field visits report recommendations implemented. Target: 95%
2016 report: the joint monitoring visits were not carried out in 2016 due to unavailability of main counterparts.
2016 Expected result 2. Indicators and targets: 1. Number of country programme board meetings organized. Target: 2 2. Number of MINEC staff trained on project management. Target: 3 3. Number of IP institutions staff attending training in RBM/PME/NIM. Target: 15Number of country programme board meetings organized. Target: 2
2016 report: 1. Number of country programme board meetings organized: 1 2. Number of MINEC staff trained on project management: 2 3. Number of IP institutions staff attending training in RBM/PME/NIM: 0
2016 AWP Expected result 3. Indicators and targets: 1. Timeliness of annual audit. Target: All submitted by end of April. 2. % of audit recommendations implemented. Target: 90%

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of country diagnostics carried out to inform policy options on national response to globally agreed development agenda, including with analysis of sustainability and risk resilience

The project aims to build on the achievements of GHD, PEI & ACAFS. This joint project framework represents an effort by the UN to coordinate and enhance the synergies between various programmes aiming to support the Government to achieve UNDAF Outcome 3.
